metadata.name: NAZCA #65
metadata.description:
Real time animation (WebGL)
Variable dimension
2022

Nazca is a group of living glyphs made in the soil of the GPU. There are 17 figures that get combined and mixed over three layers. The figures vary in complexity but are generally created with vertical and horizontal lines only. Figures have at least one seed, some even have a seed per path. A seed is an oscillating pixel that can be compared to a square wave oscillator of audio synthesis and is usually followed by a path or a set of paths. The purpose of the paths is to send the pixels along the lines to make the figures visible through movement and to create a reduction to pure animation.

ğŸ‘½ Kim Asendorf

metadata.name: "åŠ£è¯-Rekka-" #35
metadata.description:
Title: "åŠ£è¯-Rekka-"

Description:

This animation artwork explores the themes of paper replication noise and aging effects.

It portrays the gradual obscuring of details and content within drawings due to the noise generated from overlapping copies and the natural deterioration of the paper itself.

Various noise effects intricately transform the original state into a complex visual.

Try drawing shapes with parameters - objects like circles, lines, and dimension lines. Move the parameters freely to create your designs.

However, completion is short-lived.

In a matter of seconds, the copies multiply repeatedly.

Modifications, alterations, and revisions are applied to the objects.

Concurrently, the paper's decay and replication-induced noise compound on the drawing's surface.

This process repeats, archives, and...

The drawing becomes progressively more challenging to decipher.

Randomized years of passage are set.

The longer the passage, the lengthier the animation, and the more effects overlap on the drawing. Enjoy the evolving animation.

Vertical lines flow from left to right throughout the animation.

Each second represents a fictional decay of 10 years, and the year markings regress.

Origin and Creation of the Artwork:

Currently involved in the field of architecture, I've come across numerous old architectural drawings. These often prove difficult to interpret due to the obscurity caused by dirt and noise when compared to contemporary blueprints.

While deciphering these intricate drawings, the idea emerged to represent the unique replication noise of copiers. Additionally, there's a fondness for the inherent aging of paper, which imparts a sense of history. Drawings that have been cherished and preserved for years progressively deteriorate due to fading and dirt.

I aimed to combine the vintage deterioration seen in old maps and books with the noise generated by machines, creating an effect function.

The effects encompass both machine noise and aging noise.

For stochastic noise, I designed functions based on the same principles as actual photocopying. Colors are obtained from the original layer, slight discrepancies in position and color are introduced, and the color is redrawn.

For aging noise, I incorporated effects simulating wetting and drying of paper, hole formation, rust stains, and more.

Press the 's' key to save the animation as a PNG.

Due to being a beginner, there might be occasional malfunctions in parameters or hash values, and I appreciate your understanding.

Please share many of your original objects! With gratitude, I'll mix them all up:)

I hope you enjoy it.

Furthermore, I express gratitude to fxhash for allowing me to artistically manifest such ideas and share them with everyone.

Also, from my early years, I've always admired my father, who used to pore over blueprints. I think I created this work because I aspire to be like him.

åŠ£è¯-Rekka- ã«ã¤ã„ã¦ã€

metadata.name: Modern Times #43
metadata.description:
Created by Eko33, a generative artist featured at the Tezos Ecosystem Exhibition (Art Basel Miami 2021).

This generative artwork creates a limited series of distinctive artworks based on unique hash seeds.

The algorithmic approach of this collection generates a broad spectrum of unique outcomes, inspired by the "giant machine" from the movie "Modern Times."

Beyond a classic mechanical representation, Eko33 aims to convey multiple emotions while embracing the cold nature of algorithms.

Computer-generated generative art can be seen as a gigantic assembly line. Still, its true nature gives the artist complete freedom from all commercially available tools/constraints.

The collection "Modern Times" highlights the dark ages of generative arts using a bichromatic color palette and evolves toward the contemporary "Digital Renaissance" era using warmer, more acid and "pop" colors.

About Eko33:
Official fx(hash) page: https://www.fxhash.xyz/u/Eko33
Official Website: https://www.eko33.com/

metadata.name: Currency 1.0 #50
metadata.description:
Currency 1.0

This is one of a series of conceptual artworks about art and valuation. Each artwork is an exact replica of itself, so all the generative pieces look and feel the same. This work references Fxhash & Tezos eco-system and thus each token is fictionally named as FXT, but it has no relation to the official platforms. 

This artwork attempts to questions the basic premise of art valuation - does art have any value if the art itself costs nothing? Is the value of art what the anyone wants to pay for the work? Is art itself the currency, or is currency the art?

There are 2500 editions in Currency 1.0, with each edition costing 0 XTZ. 
Royalty is 10%, the minimum permitted.

Currency 1.0 @beardcoded

metadata.name: "åŠ£è¯-Rekka-" #110
metadata.description:
Title: "åŠ£è¯-Rekka-"

Description:

This animation artwork explores the themes of paper replication noise and aging effects.

It portrays the gradual obscuring of details and content within drawings due to the noise generated from overlapping copies and the natural deterioration of the paper itself.

Various noise effects intricately transform the original state into a complex visual.

Try drawing shapes with parameters - objects like circles, lines, and dimension lines. Move the parameters freely to create your designs.

However, completion is short-lived.

In a matter of seconds, the copies multiply repeatedly.

Modifications, alterations, and revisions are applied to the objects.

Concurrently, the paper's decay and replication-induced noise compound on the drawing's surface.

This process repeats, archives, and...

The drawing becomes progressively more challenging to decipher.

Randomized years of passage are set.

The longer the passage, the lengthier the animation, and the more effects overlap on the drawing. Enjoy the evolving animation.

Vertical lines flow from left to right throughout the animation.

Each second represents a fictional decay of 10 years, and the year markings regress.

Origin and Creation of the Artwork:

Currently involved in the field of architecture, I've come across numerous old architectural drawings. These often prove difficult to interpret due to the obscurity caused by dirt and noise when compared to contemporary blueprints.

While deciphering these intricate drawings, the idea emerged to represent the unique replication noise of copiers. Additionally, there's a fondness for the inherent aging of paper, which imparts a sense of history. Drawings that have been cherished and preserved for years progressively deteriorate due to fading and dirt.

I aimed to combine the vintage deterioration seen in old maps and books with the noise generated by machines, creating an effect function.

The effects encompass both machine noise and aging noise.

For stochastic noise, I designed functions based on the same principles as actual photocopying. Colors are obtained from the original layer, slight discrepancies in position and color are introduced, and the color is redrawn.

For aging noise, I incorporated effects simulating wetting and drying of paper, hole formation, rust stains, and more.

Press the 's' key to save the animation as a PNG.

Due to being a beginner, there might be occasional malfunctions in parameters or hash values, and I appreciate your understanding.

Please share many of your original objects! With gratitude, I'll mix them all up:)

I hope you enjoy it.

Furthermore, I express gratitude to fxhash for allowing me to artistically manifest such ideas and share them with everyone.

Also, from my early years, I've always admired my father, who used to pore over blueprints. I think I created this work because I aspire to be like him.

metadata.name: Liny_Dancers #14
metadata.description:
Liny_Dancers.
I wrote four lines.

The simple shapes reminded me of people are dancing.
I enjoyed it and felt happy again.

I wanted a result quite minimally.
I wanted to cram in all kinds of ideas.
But I decided against it.

The maximum number of dancers would be five dancers.

But the more dancers, It will be Rare.

I feel joy, emotion, and melancholy from the way they dance.

Please enjoy it.

metadata.description:
Artwork by loackme

metadata.description:
Artwork by loackme

metadata.name: Colorleaves #92
metadata.description:
[Pigments are accumulated in the leaves, giving them various shades. Some of the most beautiful foliage features color gradients changing as the season progresses. On some occasions, we ran out of toner.]

There is a keyboard key that unlocks more variations.

metadata.name: Colorleaves #151
metadata.description:
[Pigments are accumulated in the leaves, giving them various shades. Some of the most beautiful foliage features color gradients changing as the season progresses. On some occasions, we ran out of toner.]

There is a keyboard key that unlocks more variations.

metadata.name: Earth #212
metadata.description:
This artwork builds upon the annual Earth Day animations Iâ€™ve been making since 2009. The particle system was written from scratch in vanilla javascript (a single 22KB HTML/JS file). The particles are constrained to the surface of a sphere and exhibit "social interactions" from which life-like patterns emerge.

Each animation will be minted with a randomly assigned color palette, energy level, particle type, and social behavior. Over 900 basic phenotypes are possible, with countless subtleties expressed per phenotype. There are a few wild rarities waiting to be born as well...

This work evolved over a three day creative sprint with fellow algorithmic artist Canton Becker. We think the Earth deserves a blockchain that doesn't blow tons of carbon. This animation pays tribute to the climate scientists and tech innovators who are working to secure our future on this planet. To that end, 10% of all proceeds from this project will be donated to The Coalition for Rainforest Nations.

metadata.name: Earth #229
metadata.description:
This artwork builds upon the annual Earth Day animations Iâ€™ve been making since 2009. The particle system was written from scratch in vanilla javascript (a single 22KB HTML/JS file). The particles are constrained to the surface of a sphere and exhibit "social interactions" from which life-like patterns emerge.

Each animation will be minted with a randomly assigned color palette, energy level, particle type, and social behavior. Over 900 basic phenotypes are possible, with countless subtleties expressed per phenotype. There are a few wild rarities waiting to be born as well...

This work evolved over a three day creative sprint with fellow algorithmic artist Canton Becker. We think the Earth deserves a blockchain that doesn't blow tons of carbon. This animation pays tribute to the climate scientists and tech innovators who are working to secure our future on this planet. To that end, 10% of all proceeds from this project will be donated to The Coalition for Rainforest Nations.

metadata.name: Action Fields #346
metadata.description:
A generative painting based on abstract expressionism and the action paintings of Jackson Pollock.

Several different flow fields are used to create paths which are then painted in one of four different styles (pastel, paint, Pollock, black+gold). Additional features affect the background, path length + angles, level of detail, and mess (drips and splats). 

NOTES: 
- Some variations of the Pollock style may appear slightly different between browsers, but will render consistently in the same browser. 
- On slower devices, it may take some time to being drawing due to the background rendering.
- If you get a browser warning that the page is taking a long time, press continue.

Viewing in desktop Chrome is recommended for the best results.
Press â€™sâ€™ to save a screenshot. Image size is 1200x928px
Press â€™pâ€™ to pause/resume.

Add '&size=#' to the end of the live view URL to render a variation of your edition at a resolution from 300 to 5,000 px. The ideal higher resolution is 2,000px.

Copyright (c) 2022 Matt Perkins, hello@mattperkins.me, @nudoru on Twitter. Licensed under CC BY-NC-SA 4.0, see LICENSE.txt for more information.

metadata.name: Bloomside of The Past Field #40
metadata.description:
Made this work as a part of trying to make misprint effects, while maintaining the square form.
The scene are the flowers and other vegetations. Sometimes the scene will have the rain, snow and other weathers.

I imagined the scene was a form of painting, drawing or pictures on the postcard. So, all of them will have been signed as a loved sign, dusted sign (the spiders will come) and left unsigned. 

-----
The grain function which I used from Gorilla Sun Fx(text)
written in p5js. 
-----
my friends are married and getting married. I was left and I'm growing the flowers for myself in the sideline of the park, house, or elsewhere.

metadata.name: Coiling 2 #80
metadata.description:
COILING 2 is an experiment in weaving color to create an orbiting sphere. Each sphere grows from a randomized initial condition. The coiling then continues to expand from 256 different rules of growth, building up each sphere ring by ring. The weaving employs a cellular automata (CA) system to generate a sphere defined by a distribution of colored cells.

Description of Features

COMPOSITION: The framing or camera view of each token is inspired by a satellite view of a planet:
Horizon 40%
Quarter 25%
Perigee 14%
Binary 20%
Apogee 1%

COLOR PALETTE: The color logic is constrained across three palettes:
Pastel 70%
Jelly Bean 25%
Neon 5%

COLORATION: How the colors are related within each palette:
Contrast 65%
Bright 25%
Medium 5%
Dark 5%

GRADIENT: The overall color gradient from pole to pole of the sphere runs through 2 or 3 colors:
Three Colors 33%
Two Colors 66%

Navigation Instructions:
1. Click, Left or Right arrow to toggle between different views.
2. Space pauses animation
3. â€œiâ€ saves view as png.

metadata.name: Ersbla #284
metadata.description:
Ersbla is part of the fxhash live minting experience at Proof of People, London 2022. 

It is the third entry in a series of abstract generative experiments inspired by the graphic and textile work of Anni and Josef Albers. As a follow-up to the 'Sabler' and 'Lebras' collections, 'Ersbla' produces textile effects using a combination of thousands of tiny dots arranged on variable grids, resulting in a wide variety of unique Bauhaus-inspired compositions in a variety of palettes.

Press 'S' to save a high-resolution 2400 x 3396 px image in PNG format.

Depending on the density of your output, please allow up to a few seconds for your edition to generate.

metadata.name: cell #17
metadata.description: Works on the theme of cell division.
